content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS. The Congress finds that the United States is facing a crisis in writing skills in schools and the workplace, with nearly 1/3 of high school graduates not prepared for college-level English composition. Deficiencies in writing skills result in high private-sector costs for training, and writing is a key skill for employment and promotion. Writing is also a central feature in educational standards at all levels. The National Writing Project addresses deficiencies in writing skills, with annual private-sector costs for training as high as $3.1 billion. Writing is crucial for employment and promotion, and evaluations show significant improvements in student writing performance. The National Writing Project has been successful in improving student writing performance and classroom practices. It serves as a model for programs in various subjects and benefits over 135,000 teachers annually. The National Writing Project serves as a model for programs in various subjects, benefiting over 135,000 teachers annually in nearly 200 sites across the US. The National Writing Project, under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, is reauthorized with a focus on supporting teachers in various subjects across nearly 200 sites in the US. The purposes of the National Writing Project under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 include supporting the expansion of its network, ensuring high quality sites, disseminating effective practices, and coordinating activities with other programs. The National Writing Project is established under SEC. 2332. The Secretary is authorized to award a grant to the National Writing Project, a nonprofit organization focused on improving student writing and learning. The grant aims to enhance writing teaching and learning in classrooms by partnering with educational institutions. The grant awarded to the National Writing Project aims to improve writing teaching in classrooms by partnering with educational institutions to establish teacher training programs in effective writing approaches. The contractors will establish and operate teacher training programs for effective writing approaches, with funds from the Secretary used for the Federal share of costs. Teacher training programs authorized in subsection (a) will train teachers from kindergarten to college, select teachers for a National Writing Project teacher network, and conduct workshops for other teachers. The National Writing Project establishes a National Advisory Board composed of national educational leaders and experts in writing, with additional members as deemed necessary. The National Review Board will review and recommend applications for funding by the National Writing Project, with authorized appropriations of $30,000,000 for fiscal year 2008 and additional funding for the following 5 years.
